articles.headline: Senate, 68 to 32, Passes Overhaul for Immigration
articles.snippet: The most significant overhaul of the nation’s immigration laws in a generation passed the Senate with strong bipartisan support on Thursday, setting up a fight in the Republican-controlled House.
articles.abstract: The most significant overhaul of the nation’s immigration laws in a generation passed the Senate with strong bipartisan support on Thursday, setting up a fight in the Republican-controlled House.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Senate on Thursday approved the most significant overhaul of the nation’s immigration laws in a generation with broad support generated by a sense among leading Republicans that the party needed to join with Democrats to remove a wedge between Republicans and Hispanic voters.
articles.byline: By Ashley Parker and Jonathan Martin

articles.headline: Finance Committee Asks Senators to Start Tax Reform Process
articles.snippet: The panel’s leaders, including its chairman, Senator Max Baucus of Montana, asked colleagues to identify tax breaks, deductions and credits that they believe should be spared.
articles.abstract: The panel’s leaders, including its chairman, Senator Max Baucus of Montana, asked colleagues to identify tax breaks, deductions and credits that they believe should be spared.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Democratic and Republican leaders of the Senate Finance Committee on Thursday began a legislative push to simplify the tax code by asking all senators to identify what tax breaks, deductions and credits should be kept.

articles.headline: Suit Accuses Corzine of a Failure at the Helm
articles.snippet: Federal regulators have announced a lawsuit against Jon S. Corzine, the former chief executive of MF Global, in connection with the brokerage firm’s misuse of customer money during its final days.
articles.abstract: Federal regulators have announced a lawsuit against Jon S. Corzine, the former chief executive of MF Global, in connection with the brokerage firm’s misuse of customer money during its final days.

articles.headline: Wielding Derivatives as a Tool for Deceit
articles.snippet: Derivatives, commonly used to avoid taxes or accounting regulations, might have been used by Italy to hide its deficit upon entry into the euro zone.
articles.abstract: Derivatives, commonly used to avoid taxes or accounting regulations, might have been used by Italy to hide its deficit upon entry into the euro zone.
articles.lead_paragraph: Derivatives are not always “financial weapons of mass destruction,” as Warren Buffett famously called them.

articles.headline: Ratings Service Moody’s Finds Pension Shortfall
articles.snippet: Moody’s Investors Service, dissatisfied with the way states measure what they owe their retirees, released its own numbers on Thursday, showing that the 50 states have, in aggregate, just 48 cents for every dollar of pensions they have promised, c...
articles.abstract: Moody’s Investors Service, dissatisfied with the way states measure what they owe their retirees, released its own numbers on Thursday, showing that the 50 states have, in aggregate, just 48 cents for every dollar of pensions they have promised, compared with the 74 cents on the dollar that the states now report.
articles.lead_paragraph: Moody’s Investors Service, dissatisfied with the way states measure what they owe their retirees, released its own numbers on Thursday, showing that the 50 states have, in aggregate, just 48 cents for every dollar in pensions they have promised.

articles.headline: Roberts Pulls Supreme Court to the Right Step by Step
articles.snippet: Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. may work slowly, but he has a long-term strategy for putting his mark on the Supreme Court.
articles.abstract: Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. may work slowly, but he has a long-term strategy for putting his mark on the Supreme Court.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Viewed in isolation, the Supreme Court term that just ended had elements of modesty. The court declined to do away with affirmative action, gave Congress another shot at salvaging the Voting Rights Act and refused to find a constitutional right to same-sex marriage.

articles.headline: Public Rage Catching Up With Brazil’s Congress
articles.snippet: Laws that make it difficult to convict or dismiss members of Congress, described as “the most despised institution in Brazil,” have led to widespread public disgust.
articles.abstract: Laws that make it difficult to convict or dismiss members of Congress, described as “the most despised institution in Brazil,” have led to widespread public disgust.
articles.lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — One politician was elected to Brazil’s Congress while under investigation for murder after having an adversary killed with a chain saw. Another is wanted by Interpol after being found guilty of diverting more than $10 million from a public road project to offshore bank accounts.

articles.headline: A Bill Allowing More Foreign Workers Stirs a Tech Debate
articles.snippet: As the Senate voted on an immigration bill that would let Silicon Valley companies import engineers from abroad, the labor lobby said eligible workers in the United States were being passed over.
articles.abstract: As the Senate voted on an immigration bill that would let Silicon Valley companies import engineers from abroad, the labor lobby said eligible workers in the United States were being passed over.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — As the Senate voted on a landmark immigration bill that would let Silicon Valley companies import more foreign engineers, some Americans remain locked in a deeply emotional argument over whether outsiders are taking jobs away from people like Joey Doernberg.

articles.headline: BlackBerry Posts Loss, Despite New Phone
articles.snippet: BlackBerry recorded a bigger-than-expected loss for its latest quarter, although revenue rose from a year ago.
articles.abstract: BlackBerry recorded a bigger-than-expected loss for its latest quarter, although revenue rose from a year ago.
articles.lead_paragraph: 8:59 p.m. | Updated Additional reporting and analysis were added to this post.

articles.headline: Uncertainty at the Fed as Markets Oscillate
articles.snippet: The president’s all but confirmation that the Federal Reserve chairman would not be reappointed at year’s end complicated an already delicate task.
articles.abstract: The president’s all but confirmation that the Federal Reserve chairman would not be reappointed at year’s end complicated an already delicate task.
articles.lead_paragraph: It can’t have been the send-off that the Federal Reserve chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, was hoping for.
